column4: Say, if I want to do hibernation, does that mean I need 2 swap partitions, one for normal use, and one, the size of my memory, for swsup?
or is all this automatic nowdays? (I'm installing ubuntu on my first notebook)
you'd think the swap, if in use, would not do well on resuming if it was overwritten with memory
would hibernation simply fail?
just make one, 2xram
hrm. that seems again like a bad idea.  what happens if the swap gets used to 1x + y point?
I'm basically seeking reassurence it is reliable, otherwise if it isn't, how to tell swap to use a partition reserved just for it
so far you guys haven't been very reassurring ;)
if your swap usage is > ram size, using the system will be a problem, not hibernating :)
no no
my point is lets say I'm using, oh, openoffice, firefox, gimp, inkscape, maybe running tomcat and eclipse...
I'm sucking up memory, and I am using not only 2GiB of memory but also, oh, 2.1GiB of swap
and I try to hibernate
seems there simply won't be enough swap.  what happens then?
this is in a scenario of 4GiB of swap, 2GiB of memory
hibernating a system with such an high memory usage is insane :)
um. my point is I'd like a system that should work reliably :-p
your response implies to me my intuition is correct. there'd be trouble
hibernation is not reliably on linux, at least in general
ugh. fine. 1x of swap and just being careful :-/
I'd just as soon give swsup its own partition, but if that's not normal/possible, will just not worry about it :-/
is is possible, not normal
So, now that http://www.wolfire.com/humble has been FOSS'd, does that mean you guys will be adding 'em to the ubuntu gaming repo?
probably yes
